text:

PROFESSOR: So today we're
going to talk about cooking and stoves and
charcoal and then there will be plenty of
time afterwards
to work on your project stuff. Ken is here already. [INAUDIBLE] is around here.

And Amelia will
be coming at 2:00, so everyone has a
mentor to work with.

Yeah. So we did the labs in reverse. So charcoal, we did
the lab on Wednesday.

And even though
it's warmer today, I think the rain would have
made it even less pleasant. So I think that
was the right call.

So we'll go through
that a little bit more. Yeah, and I just
explained everything else.

So let's start just by
talking about cooking in developing countries. So what do people cook and what
are their needs for cooking?
Soups. Sweet potato.

And how do they
typically prepare that?

There's a wide variety. But what are some of
the cooking things that you need to be able to
do from an energy perspective?
STUDENT: Boil water.
PROFESSOR: Anything else? STUDENT: [INAUDIBLE]. PROFESSOR: Yeah. So that would be oven.
STUDENT: Grinding. PROFESSOR: Yeah.
OK. Cool, what else? Meat.

And what do you do
with meet energy wise? I'm sorry? Open fire.
Anything else? So stew.
Anything else?
What else? Rice.
And that would be-- is that captured here? Yeah. Anything else?
Beans.

STUDENT: Do you
need high pressure for anything [INAUDIBLE]?

PROFESSOR: Pressure
cookers exist. You don't see them a lot. STUDENT: You don't need
pressure for anything, do you?
PROFESSOR: No.  OK. So this is a modest list.

But some things
that are missing are

bread is a staple
in a lot of places, whether it's a tortilla or an
Indian flatbread or-- yeah?

STUDENT: No, I mean,
I'm just wondering. [INAUDIBLE] mentioned
the pressure cooker. How do you cook meat
without a pressure cooker?

Like how would you
reach that temperature? Like if you wanted
to cook it in water, wouldn't the water just boil
if you don't pressurize it?

Won't it just evaporate
if you don't-- PROFESSOR: So most
people don't boil meat.

STUDENT: Oh, so they
don't need water when they're preparing it. [INAUDIBLE] PROFESSOR: So yeah, so
I'm not saying that--

this might be a confusing
way to present this. I'm not saying that
every one of these requires every one of these.

Just that these are some of
the foods that you're cooking and these are some of the ways
that you're preparing them.

So I'm just trying to make sure
that all of these are captured or that all the methods are
captured but not linking--

yeah, because I would
be reluctant to eat boiled meat straight
without any other preparing.

Though I think cabbage and
corned beef and cabbage is boiled. So I think you can do it.
STUDENT: Vegetables. PROFESSOR: Vegetables? Yeah.

Yep. So meat is kind of uncommon
on most people's staples.

So you get it infrequently. Rice and beans or other combos
that make whole proteins

are pretty common. And a lot of people
live on rice and beans pretty much every
day of their lives

with some tortillas sometimes,
in Nicaragua certainly. Vegetables.

Oftentimes you grow some
vegetables and they supplement, but you'll live on a
staple of rice and beans

a lot of where we're working. And in terms of the cooking,
so for all of these,

there's the range
of you need low heat or you could need high heat.
You can need an oven.

So talking about direct
fire hitting the pan, hitting the food versus an oven
is going to be more convective.

And then-- yeah, and people are
pretty picky about the control

of their fire for most of
the-- or the heating source for most of these options. And so you'll see--
the people who

go to [? Grupo Fenix ?]
will definitely see this. I don't know about
also [INAUDIBLE].. But in [? Grupo Fenix, ?] a
lot of women or a few women

have gas stoves, but they still
maintain their old style adobe wood because they will only
cook their tortillas on wood.

They just can't
cook on gas in a way

that they believe makes
an acceptable tortilla. So that is one of the things
that I want to emphasize today,

I'm going to keep
coming back to it, is that people
understandably are very sensitive to how they cook
and have very long standing

traditions. They are cooking the same
way their moms cooked and their moms and their moms. And so proposing to someone to
cook in a radically different

way is challenging and
is something people are going to resist for
really understandable reasons.

So we've got the low heat,
the high heat, and the oven. That sort of captures it all.

With boiling water, you
need high enough heat that you can
actually boil water.

And each of those is
critical to most people. You can't cook with 0,
with only one, ideally.

And so people who even just cook
on three stone fires with wood just get really
good at regulating.

The oven is the optional
one that's the bonus. But people who
cook with wood get

really good at regulating
their fire so that they can get their low heat
or their high heat, depending on what they
want, because most people
need to be able to do both.

So what fuels are
typically used?

Wood, yep. [LAUGHS] I'm not asking radically
crazy questions.

I think there's another one that
might come out in your mind. Yes. STUDENT: [INAUDIBLE].
PROFESSOR: Yep.
STUDENT: Propane. PROFESSOR: Yep.  STUDENT: Kerosene maybe.

PROFESSOR: Some people also
cook with just general biomass. So that might be corn
stalks or hay or similar.

It's not a great fire, but
if it's what you've got, it's better than nothing. Because one thing to
note on most of these is

can get away with not cooking
some of your vegetables depending on how you
fertilize them if you did.

But you can't cook bread or you
can't skip cooking all of these

and expect to be
able to digest them. So cooking is a non-negotiable.

It's our basic
human need, which is part of why there's such a
high level of risk aversion,

because you're asking people
to change what they know is the thing that's keeping them
alive and their family alive.

So some things to just keep in
mind generally about cooking

is that all modern fuel increase
with income except kerosene.

So people tend to
go from wood, well,

from dung to wood to charcoal
to propane and kerosene.

But then, well, to kerosene
and then to propane. But people tend to stick
to propane for a while because it's readily available.

And people get used to it. In urban areas,
unsurprisingly, biomass

is less common than
in rural areas. And in those rural areas, people
often just stick with biomass

forever because-- so even if you can afford
it, it's still easier

to get wood that you can chop
down basically in your backyard than to go get propane.

So you'll stick with it. And then another
thing to think about is that even if people
have enough income,

if you can't get your
LPG or electric stoves or whatever, if you
don't have electricity,

you don't have the
infrastructure, you're not going to switch. And then we often
think about what I just

said about going into your
quote "backyard" to gather wood. But a lot of people in
relatively rural areas

purchase their wood
rather than collecting it, either for time reasons
or because it's actually

there's so much deforestation
that it's really hard to get the wood both in
terms of distance

and in terms of legality,
because often it's cutting down wood on other people's property.

And so you are avoiding doing
the directly illegal thing

and just purchasing it. It's less common in Central
America where we'll be going.

But in a lot of regions,
cutting down wood for fuel is now a crime.

But there is no
alternative cooking method, and so it still happens,
but now it's illegal.

And so it's become more
challenging in that respect and more expensive.

In terms of how people
cook, it really ranges. In places that have
similar levels of wealth,

you can see huge variations. So there's LPG, electricity,
kerosene, and wood.

In Guatemala, whereas
here in Ghana, wood is really used very
little and charcoal really

is used quite a bit more. So it varies place to
place what people use.

And a lot of that has to do
with how far away the wood is and therefore how expensive it
is and a lot of other factors.

But you should not assume,
this goes back to week one, everyone cooks with wood
in a developing country.

It's very location
specific and even location within the country specific
what people are doing.

The challenges with
fuel are that it can be up to a third of people's
income just to pay for fuel.

And a third of your
income is kind of insane if you imagine spending a
third of your income on fuel.

The poorest people in
the US are the ones who are paying the most
are paying less than 1% of their income on cooking fuel.

So if you imagine
going from something that cost you 1% of
your income to 30%,

that's getting
really substantial. And people who are collecting
it are sometimes in some areas spending up to seven hours
a day collecting firewood,

which is basically the
same impact on your family that if you're spending
seven hours a day,

you're not having any
time to do anything else but get enough fuel
for cooking your food.

And then just
looking at the energy densities of all of these. So wood charcoal
and the charcoal

that we made on Wednesday is
very similar to wood charcoal. You can get really
good wood charcoal

that's better than ours
and you can get really junky wood charcoal
that's worse than ours. So we're about in
the middle there.

Everything else
that's a biomass, because it's not
compressed and/or processed

is going to be worse. Dung is quite poor, both on
energy density as well as

health because you can
imagine burning dung is worse than burning anything else.

And then heating oil,
all the things that we're used to generally,
gas or electric, well,

electric doesn't
really fit in here, but gas is certainly
a whole lot better. And so of course,
people are going

to switch to here if
they can, but it's expensive and challenging.

And just from a
visual standpoint, these are all the cooking
options to think about.

So there's electricity,
propane, wood.

These are typically wood ovens. Dung. This is the Jiko stove that I'll
show a little bit later, which

can be used with charcoal. There's cooking,
and then there's a variety of different cooking
stoves that you can cook with.

And then this is just
a three stone fire. So you can see there's three
stones here to support your pot

and then you feed your logs
in this way to cook your food.

So that's just a quick
overview on cooking. We're going to get into it more. But I wanted to switch gears
and do a quick estimation.

And it says in teams of two. If you want to do it in three
or four, that's fine too. But what's the energy required
to boil a liter of water

and what's the
efficiency to do so?
Go.

Yeah. So I want to talk a little bit
about design considerations for stoves.

Some of you may be
working on those projects. So what do you think
you have to worry about when you design a stove?
STUDENT: Air flow. PROFESSOR: Air flow, yes.
Definitely. What else? STUDENT: Insulation.

PROFESSOR: Yep. STUDENT: The environment. PROFESSOR: The
environment you're in.

STUDENT: As in close
proximity, your environment, making sure there is
nothing flammable nearby. [INAUDIBLE]
PROFESSOR: So safety. STUDENT: [INAUDIBLE]
PROFESSOR: Yep. STUDENT: Size? PROFESSOR: Size? Yeah.
STUDENT: Heat source. PROFESSOR: Heat source.
STUDENT: Price.
PROFESSOR: Anything else? STUDENT: Usability.

PROFESSOR: Yeah. So if you're cooking
outside, certainly.

I think I'm below the
magic line, aren't I?
Anything else? STUDENT: Aesthetics. PROFESSOR: Yep.

STUDENT: Convenience as in how
long it takes, time to use.

[INAUDIBLE] falls
under usability but whether or not it's intuitive. Usability is already
written [INAUDIBLE]..
PROFESSOR: So it is.  All right. Well, this is a good start.

To just give you a sense
of the list that I came up with with another
person, there's

the insulation and
the thermal mass. And this is actually
a complicated issue,

because in some cases,
like with an oven, you want really, really
good thermal mass.

So you heat up that thermal
mass and then that thermal mass

allows you to cook longer,
whereas for a charcoal stove, you don't want a
big thermal mass.

You don't want necessarily
0 thermal mass. But if you have too
much thermal mass, the charcoal will
use all its energy

in transferring it to the
stove and you won't be able to cook very much with it.

Air flow is another
important consideration. The reason the Jiko worked
so poorly on Wednesday

was actually because the
door never got opened. That was my fault. I
realized that after when

I was cleaning up
then we never opened the door, which meant
there was no airflow, which pretty much limits the ability
of the fuel to get hot.

The volume. So yeah, which we mentioned,
how much you're going to cook is huge. People have really
varying needs there.

Robustness to water. So the Jiko, one of the
challenges with it is it's made of ceramic, which makes
a really nice insulator.

But as we talked about,
if you pour water onto it to prevent the--

to put out the charcoal, the
ceramic is going to crack.

And also if you drop it, the
ceramic is going to crack. But boiling water it's
pretty common for some water to run over the
edge of the stove.

And so that alone
can cause cracking. The cost of the device
is really critical,

as this is such a
fundamental need. Everyone needs one. And so if it's unaffordable,
that's pretty problematic.

Longevity is another concern. A lot of these metal
stoves that I'll be showing in a second don't
have a lot of longevity,

but they are affordable. And so Paul [INAUDIBLE]
would be really happy with that balancing act.

Other people would be less
happy, but it is an issue. The heating options.

So ideally you could
have some magic stove where you could use any fuel.

You could use charcoal or wood
or regular biomass or propane

or electricity or
whatever you could get. You'd have this magic stove. But that's not very realistic
from the price standpoint.

but people do like to be able
to cook with a range of fuels. Ease of use is
definitely important.

If it's hard to light
or hard to keep the fire lit or hard to get your pot on. It's pretty unfortunate stove.

Emissions is another thing
to think about in terms of where does the smoke go.

A lot of times it goes
straight into the kitchen. You'll see in the
homes in Nicaragua,

the stoves look a lot like this. And even when they
do have a chimney, it's rare that all three holes
for the pots are covered.

And so the chimney
in that situation doesn't work very well. A lot of the smoke escapes.

Efficiency. So how much of the heat
actually gets to cook as opposed

to doing something else. Style, aesthetics are
all pretty important. People do want their
Kitchens to be attractive.

And so while we're not
talking about a criteria

similar to does it look
like the stainless steel kitchen in a high end kitchen
or a professional stove

in a high end kitchen
in the US, it's still a really critical
thing to think about. And a really junky looking
stove will not do very well.

And then flexibility for
cooking with different fuels or different types of
foods, et cetera, et cetera.

So I'm just going to-- if we can turn it around
to go to the back corner

and show you a wide
variety of stoves. So this is one of the
stoves we used yesterday.

And it's a pretty
simple wood stove that's a relatively common design. So you can see that it has the
upper surface for cooking with.

I'm not really sure
what these decorative-- if these are just
decorative or if there's some purpose to them.

But it did prevent us from
using a certain pot yesterday, so it was a frustrating element.

STUDENT: [INAUDIBLE] PROFESSOR: Yeah. So it might be to hold a
special type of pot, absolutely.

And then a place
to catch the ash is pretty handy as well so
that the ash doesn't just

fall on the ground. And it has plenty of holes
to allow for airflow.

The Jiko, These two
are called Jikos,

which is a design of a stove
that was developed in Africa,

in Kenya I believe. And the Jiko has a ceramic
part that holds your fuel

and also acts as an insulator
and then metal everywhere else. This one was not
made as carefully

and may be a knockoff
of this one, which

you can see the ceramic liner
is actually thicker on this one. So it works a little better.

It has the door that allows
you to control airflow. So that's a big improvement over
this one and the insulation.

It has these three
pieces, which allow you to hold a smaller pot.

It has little handles that
may or may not work too well. This is pretty heavy
for such small handles, so I don't like actually
carrying it like that.

But it's a quite improved stove. And in terms of efficiency, I
believe it cuts fuel use down

by like 30%. So it's significant. This is an interesting
stove that I don't know,
can you see this at all Eric? OK, great.

So this is a knockoff Jiko. And so you can see that it
kind of looks like the Jiko

but it's got a bigger door. It has some really monstrous
handles that are actually easier to use than those.

So that's a big improvement. But it actually has so
much thermal mass in it that it gets to that issue of
there's so much thermal mass

that you use all your
fuel heating the stove rather than cooking. And so it takes forever
to cook with this.

Like a ridiculous
amount of time. And so it's one of those,
well, if this much insulation

is good, this must
be better assumption that is really common. We actually with our
charcoal we found

that if we make a charcoal-- that people like-- or
I'll talk about it more.

But a bigger piece of charcoal
that they can cut in half and make into the same
pieces of charcoal that

are identical in size, but
they prefer the bigger size. And same with stoves. People tend to bigger is
better is the assumption.

These next four I'm going
to show our all stoves I

bought in Nicaragua. So this one is cool
because it was a tire hub.

So a nice use of recycling. These legs allowed
it to actually be at this height,
which is pretty great.

However, for bringing
it back on the airplane, I cut off the legs.

Mostly charcoal in
Nicaragua is used just for frying up food at
places called fritangas.

And so they're just done
on the street corners and as a sales thing. It's rare to see these
in people's homes.

This is one, can even tell
what this is made out of?

So it's actually a gas cylinder
that got cut up probably when it died.

And then rebar is the grating.  This one is really,
really simple

and just used out
of sheet metal. It's galvanized. So if you use it inside, it's
going to make people sick,

because the galvanized
metal gives off fumes that are not so great. And then this one is
an interesting design

that's pretty common,
usually made out of a-- it's usually bigger. It's like a 55 gallon drum,
but I couldn't bring that home

on the airplane. And this one is
interesting because it allows you to use charcoal
or wood because you

can feed the wood in
this way like would in a traditional adobe stove. And so it's nice that it does
have that flexibility compared
to all the others.

And all of them
generally come painted and then the paint all chips
away as you cook with it.

But that does speak to
the aesthetics interest that people want to buy a
nice looking painted stove even if the paint
doesn't last very long.

It helps them sell. Yeah? STUDENT: One of the
ones that we [INAUDIBLE] last year was really easy
to make with sheet metal.

Is that really important
in a device or [INAUDIBLE]?? PROFESSOR: So what
that team identified

was that it was
important that this be made by the women locally. And so therefore, they
decided that a single piece

of sheet metal was going
to be easier for the women to make locally than making
it out of many pieces.

You as a team, if you end
up working on a project, may come to a
different conclusion. That's the conclusion
they came up with.

Yeah? STUDENT: Do they have
access to welding?

PROFESSOR: So in
Nicaragua there's plenty of people who well,
mostly with oxyacetylene or stick welding.

But in the rural
villages, there aren't. And so for example, in
where Grupo Fenix is,

there isn't a welder in the
village, in the community. But if you went up to Ocotal,
you can find people who weld.

So there's definitely
welding capability. You should consider that local. But it's not something that the
women in the village could do.

And so that's why they didn't
come up with a welded stove was because they wanted to be
something that the women could do themselves.

So two really good resources are
cookstove.net, which goes more

into the theory of
cookstoves, and Aprovecho, which is a huge organization
that does a lot of stove design

and testing. And they have a lot
of great resources about how to design stoves,
how to test stoves, et cetera.

Are there any other
questions about stoves?

OK. So I'm going to talk
some more about charcoal. So 2 and 1/2 billion
people cook with biomass.

So that's the market
we're talking about, as opposed to people cooking
with gas or electricity.

And it's generally people living
on less than $2 or $3 a day, though there is some
wide range on that.

And there's really no
viable alternative. I'll talk about solar
cookers a little later.

Propane fuel is just
unavailable and same with the grid in these regions.

And so cooking with biomass,
which I got into a little, has some real problems.

So there's 1 million
and 1/2 people who die every year from
indoor air pollution, and that's generally
associated with cooking

inside the home,
smoking inside the home. There's other things
that also contribute, but indoor air pollution
from cooking is a huge one.

And it's mostly
women and children who are the ones
tending the fires and taking the biggest hit here. So there was a study
done that estimated

that if everyone who currently
cooks with wood or dung and straw and biomass that's
raw switched to charcoal,

half of those lives
would be saved right off the bat with no added
ventilation, no other changes,

just switching from wood to
charcoal because it's that much cleaner. But then you get into
the environmental issue

of we're talking
about regions that can be facing 6% to 10%
deforestation rates in areas

that are up to 98% deforested. And so if you encourage
everyone to switch to charcoal,

you're going to be
using up more wood and you're going to decimate
the environment even further.

And as I mentioned
before, there's also a poverty aspect
to cooking fuel in terms of how much
money and/or time it

takes to be able to cook. So the charcoal that we
talked about on Wednesday

has some benefits in
that it burns as cleanly as wood charcoal. It's using a true waste.

The complicated part
about using a true waste is that in every region,
some of the possible wastes

are not true wastes. And so corncobs and stalks
can be used in farms

or any of these materials
can be used in farms to replenish the soil basically
except sugarcane, which really has no nutritive
value once you

press the sugar out of it. And so in places
where people are using that to
replenish the soil,

it's a really bad
idea to encourage them to switch to
making charcoal from it because they're going
to decimate their land

and the land is so valuable. However, in most farms that
are at the subsistence level,

you can find some
biomass that's rotting. And so that's the
biomass we target. So that's why we try
to have a process that

works with a huge
variety of waste so that you can use a
wide variety of waste and only use the
stuff that's waste.

The nice thing about
using the true waste is that it tends to be
rotting in such a way that it's producing a
lot of methane gas, which

is one of the worst
greenhouse gases and worse for the environment
than burning the material.

And so they're actually areas
where you get carbon credits just for burning sugarcane waste
rather than letting it rot.

And so here rather than
just helping the environment by burning it, we're using
that fuel to cook with

as well as not getting the
methane in the environment. So just to give you a sense
of where this project is,

so a few years ago, we
got a $200,000 grant from the World Bank
to make charcoal.

And so we trained more
than 1,000 people in Haiti in the method and we have some
workshops or ateliers in Haiti

that are making
the charcoal now. Typically the costs associated
with the charcoal or just

the drum and the press. And so the drum is anywhere
from $10 to $30 in a country

and the press generally
is about $2 to make. If someone's telling you
they're going to make it for 10,

they're ripping you
off, so push back. Because most people do
when you talk to welders,

most people talk about
how expensive it is. But if you push, $2 is
a pretty standard price

we found almost everywhere. So the process that we
went through yesterday

was we took the raw waste, wrote
it into a drum, lit it on fire, covered it, then you're in an
anaerobic environment for about

two hours, and then you have
your charcoal finds, which you crush in the bag in a bag
method and the rice husks mixed

with the binder made
from yucca, briquette it, and then you can put
the briquettes back

in the drum to harden
them after they've dried, and then you can cook with them. So I just want to make
sure that you guys are all

comfortable with this method,
because you'll be doing it. Most of you will be doing
it having only done it once.

And so I just want to make
sure you are feeling confident.

And so that's why I'm
reviewing it in so much detail. So when you load
the drum, you need to remember to have
the stick in the middle

to make your chimney. You can use the fuses at the
bottom to help light the drum. And it works really well to
light from the bottom rather

than the top. If you just light
from the top, you'll get much less effective burning.

When you're covering
up the drum, again, first you see this smoke. And actually, we saw very
little of the just white smoke.

We saw mostly yellow smoke. The just white smoke is water. And so if you're getting
a ton of just white smoke,

that means your
waste is too dry. You're almost never going
to see it as dry as we had
on Wednesday, because that-- too wet, excuse me. Too dry.

So you almost never see it as
dry as we had on Wednesday, because that has been sitting
in a heated, incredibly

dry environment at
MIT for about a year. And so that helps it
dry out at a level that you're never going
to see in the field.

That's why it was
infected with cockroaches because of all those-- because it was spending so
long in the bowels of MIT.

So you will see
some white smoke. But if that's all
you're getting, that's an indicator that
your stuff is too wet. Or if the drum just won't
catch on fire at all.

And then you get
the yellow smoke and then you get the
flame and then you wait some period of time.

And I'm sorry I can't give you
a seven minutes answer for how long you wait until you switch.

Of the yellow smoke
and so you want to wait until you're
no longer getting those puffs of yellow smoke,
because those are areas that

haven't gotten any
heat yet that are now starting to catch on fire. And then later on what
cued me to cover it up

was we were starting
to get black smoke. And the black smoke
tends to mean that we're burning everything really fast.

And so that's why we
needed to cover it up. But it is a judgment
call and it is tricky. And so there's no easy way.

Everything from the humidity
to the temperature to the type of the way-- what was in the drum before.

That's another thing
to think about is if when you get an oil
drum, you don't know where you're getting it from. And so it may have oil in it.

And so you may need
to do like a pre burn with just a
little bit of material to burn out whatever
junk is in the drum

so that you have a clean-ish
drum to use for carbonization, because you wouldn't want
oil impregnated briquettes,

because that would
burn pretty nastily. And you can do side
by side carbonization

if you have a few
drums, which is nice. And then covering it up, just
doing it relatively quickly

but also carefully
so you don't get burned, because the drum is
really hot at that point.

For making the binder,
just remembering that you're going for this
really snot-like consistency.

So checking and make sure
you get it before you use it. Because if you
don't, the briquettes will completely fall apart,
and that's problematic.

And then using the right
amount so that you actually get a good briquette is important.

And then briquetting--
so I just wanted to show you a couple of other

to wail on this press to make briquettes well. And 2009, they made
an extruding device

to make briquettes, which is

hit it a few times,
and then when you open, this plate at the bottom has

came up with an improvement,

some of the improvements were instead of loading
from the very top, which required a lot more precision,

And for ejecting, instead

down. And then we actually--
well, actually I can show you the presses. They're over here.

down here, it has this plate.

drops down there like that plunger is trying to.
